author: abcoathup
content:
EIP authors want numbers that have meaning to them. It is difficult to determine ahead of time what is meaningful to an author and what isn't.

I was formulating an EIP and ideally wanted a specific number.  I check the EIP repo almost every weekday, so when I saw the number I wanted coming up, I knew I needed to get my draft ready.
The number came up faster than I expected so I lunged at it when I saw it was available and manually opened a PR but didn't use bots and didn't create spam issues.

I was absolutely gutted to then get a different number issued by an editor but accepted it as a fair call.
 https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/4888#discussion_r823565852

I wanted a specific number and I opened a PR when it wasn't ready.  **I was guilty on two counts and the number was appropriately changed as per the current policy to reduce authors from attempting to snipe numbers.**

author: abcoathup
content:
The perception is that "insiders" get treated differently rather than a consistent approach.
Random numbers would remove this perception around EIP numbers.

PR/4444 didn't have its number changed even though PR/4439, PR/4440, PR/4441, PR/4442, PR/4443, were all opened within a minute of each other, in possible attempt to farm a number.
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/4444#discussion_r746638232

PR/4844 didn't have its number changed even though PR/4843 was missing for unknown reasons. (GitHub can remove spam issues/PRs)
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/4844#issuecomment-1051648685

PR/4888 number was changed to a non-PR number for a manually created PR for a too early draft
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/4888#discussion_r823565852

PR/5000 was requested to change its number for a bot created PR with spam issues prior and another editor merged the PR later without a number change
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/5000#discussion_r850655921

PR/5222 number was changed to a non-PR number
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/5222#discussion_r918475494

author: samwilsn
content: occasionally github completely removes spam issues/prs

author: samwilsn
content: so it's not entirely unusual

author: abcoathup
content:
It is about perception, which is why my vote is for random numbers.  

The two PRs with numbers changed were for non-"insiders".  The two PRs which were merged without a number changed appeared to involve "insiders".

The goal is to reduce issue spam and any perception of preferential treatment.
EIP editors have enough to do without having to get into controversy about numbers which only the EIP authors care about.

author: abcoathup
content: I have removed the word suspicious and changed to missing for unknown reasons. (GitHub can remove spam issues/PRs)

author: sky.cactus
content: I think it is useful to include <https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/4444#pullrequestreview-802661243> in your list.  It was farmed, but by doing useful work leading up to the PR.  I use this as an example of how fuzzy the line can be between abusive behavior and helpful behavior around gaming the system.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@689161464829050960> I think I'm coming around to your PR to just renumber 5000 to 5159.  If we can get more support on that then on my PR I would be okay with it.

author: abcoathup

author: sky.cactus
content: I think this is one of the options proposed by Sam (though 1,100 for a bit more variability and so someone can't just create 10 EIPs in hopes that one lands with the desired number).

author: killari.
content: if you create 10 eips, they will all be separated by [1,10]

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, true.  So you get a few chances to hit the number you want, but once you pass it there is no going back.

author: killari.
content: right, and they have to be good enough eips to get a number

author: sky.cactus
content: Right, and be merged around the same time without anything else being merged in-between.  This is probably a sufficient deterrent for our needs.

author: hrkrshnn
content: Our data shows that none of the merged PRs so far were renumbered. This arbitrary renumbering seems to be something relatively new. You should fight for keeping 4888. In the case of 5222, the decision to renumber seems to be reverted after us pointing out how it looked like bullying new contributors with allegations of number squatting and forcefully getting their EIPs renumbered. With Micah's insistence on pursuing the auctioning idea, one needs to really ponder on what's the true motivation for this number policing.

author: sky.cactus
content: In case it isn't clear in the prior conversations, the issue here has little to do with the number sniping (though that is a problem, it isn't the primary one) and much more to do with how the sniping was handled by the editors.  Sam assigned a number (per our policy that editors assign numbers), and then lightclient overruled that without any public discussion from the authors or lightclient.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the argument could be formulated something like, "An in-person/private conversation resulted in the authors receiving EIP-5000.  We do not know what, if anything, the editor received in exchange as we can only see the publicly visible outcome of the private engagement."  I personally *suspect* that the editor received nothing except a thanks/reputation in exchange, but from a public perception point of view what I *suspect* happened doesn't matter.  The problem here is that the usual operating policy of "editors assign numbers" and "when editors disagree, they discuss publicly" wasn't followed and we don't know why so we can only guess as to the reasoning/motivations about what happened behind the closed doors.  This is why we prefer to do everything in public, to minimize the uncertainty around why decisions are being made.

author: leonardoalt
content: That's not enough to start accusing people without proof.

author: killari.
content: I am not accusing anyone

author: leonardoalt
content: Sure, I understand that. But what's happening here is also that from an internal perception accusations are being made without proof, or even evidence, that a deal happened. This is defamatory and dishonest.

author: killari.

author: sky.cactus
